content: Public and private health care spending is increasing due to factors like rising health insurance enrollment and an aging population. The tax subsidies in the Internal Revenue Code for health care are often overlooked in budget discussions, as they provide preferential tax treatment for certain forms of income. Congressional focus on health-related tax expenditures is important. Congressional attention to health-related tax expenditures focuses on the value of these provisions, changes over time, impact of the ACA, and comparison to total revenue collected. It also examines the size of health tax expenditures relative to federal spending on health programs. This report analyzes historical data on health-related tax expenditure estimates published by the Joint Committee on Taxation (JCT) to provide insights into the value of total revenue collected and the size of health tax expenditures relative to federal spending on health programs. The values of health-related tax expenditures historically exceeded health discretionary outlays, but were still much less than health mandatory outlays.
